Issues.Title: WinForms designer debugging is not working for netcore app
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/main/docs/issue-guide.md -->

* .NET Core Version: 
NetCore 3.1 and recent version

VS: VS2019

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
No

**Problem description:**

I trying to do designer debugging for my WinForms net core application using devenv.exe, but the breakpoint is never hit the source. Is designer debugging working in NETCore application.


**Expected behavior:**
The WinForms designer debugging should work.



**Minimal repro:**
Steps to reproduce:

1. In the attached project, I have created a custom button control with Property Called MyText.

2. Open the project setting and Select the Debug tab.

3. Choose the Launch Executables option. ---> Note: In Framework, it will display as Start with External Program.

4. Choose devenv exe location as the executable path.

5. Then Put the breakpoint in the MyText property setter of CustomButton class.

6. Then Click start program to start debugging.

7. Then click the WinformformsApp1 in the recent list.

8. Open the Form1 designer in the newly open VS instance.

10. Then Change MyText property value in design time.

11.Now the Setter of MyText property should be hit while changing its value. But breakpoint won't hit.

The Same scenario working fine in the 4.6 or less Framework application.

**Project:** 
[169259-windowsformsapp1-copy.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/6006962/169259-windowsformsapp1-copy.zip)


**Reproducible Video:** 
[169273-debugvideo.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/6006964/169273-debugvideo.zip)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "WinForms designer debugging is not working for netcore app" (#4583)

Issues.Title: ComboBox does not handle DataBindings and empty BindingLists
Issues.Body:
* .NET Framwork Version: 
.NET Framework 4.7.2

**Problem description:**
Problem 1:
If a BindingList is set as the DataSource for a default ComboBox and the BindingList is/gets empty,
on adding Items to the BindingList neither events (SelectedIndexChanged) are fired nor any
additional DataBindings are taken care of.

Problem 2:
DataBindings generally need the WriteValue() function called from the SelectionChangeCommitted event
in order to get set from the GUI ComboBox, which is an unnecessary workaround.

**Expected behavior:**
I set a empty BindingList as DataSource for the ComboBox and setup additional Databindings.
When adding an item to the empty BindingList the SelectedItemChanged, TextUpdate, SelectedIndexChanged
and SelectedValueChanged events of the ComboBox should fire and all associated DataBindings should get
updated/set (e.g. SelectedItem).
Selecting an item via GUI should update/set associated DataBinding without additional
function calls from events.

**Minimal repro:**
https://github.com/KingMetal7/ComboBox_Bug.git
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "ComboBox does not handle DataBindings and empty BindingLists" (#4582)

Issues.Title: Control Arrays in Design Mode
Issues.Body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

I'd like to see a similar solution to the one implemented in VB6 for Control Arrays in Design Mode. When can this be useful? When you have complex cases like this one:

[![Many labels in a window form][2]][2]

I had over 500 pictures that handled an Odontogram. This case was impossible to migrate to .NET because it would have involved a considerable re-engineering process from my side. Also, I believe a similar feature could be brought to **MAUI, WPF, and Avalonia**. This would increase the flexibility when you have to handle multiple related controls.

**Describe the solution you'd like and alternatives you've considered**

After reading several forums over the years, I was able to write this piece of code that more or less fixed "the problem" of Control Arrays in Design Mode. The example uses a series of **Label controls** created in Design Mode.

[![Many labels in a window form][1]][1]

### Code examples:

**VB.NET:**

```vb
Public Class Form1

    'To declare the List of controls
    Dim labels As New List(Of Label)()

    Private Sub Form1_Load(sender As Object, e As EventArgs) Handles MyBase.Load
        'To get all controls in the form
        For Each control In Me.Controls
            'To search for the specific type that you want to create the array 
            If control.[GetType]().Name.Contains("Label") Then
                'To add the control to the List
                labels.Add(DirectCast(control, Label))
            End If
        Next
        'To sort the labels by the ID
        labels = labels.OrderBy(Function(x) x.Name).ToList()
    End Sub
End Class
```

**C#:**

```csharp
public class Form1
{

    // To declare the List of controls
    private List<Label> labels = new List<Label>();

    private void Form1_Load(object sender, EventArgs e)
    {
        // To get all controls in the form
        foreach (var control in this.Controls)
        {
            // To search for the specific type that you want to create the array 
            if (control.GetType().Name.Contains("Label"))
                // To add the control to the List
                labels.Add((Label)control);
        }
        // To sort the labels by the ID
        labels = labels.OrderBy(x => x.Name).ToList();
    }
}
```

I used a **List** for convenient reasons, but with the pieces of code I shared, anyone can create in design time the controls that they need, and while they keep the "index" as the last character (label**1**, label**2**, ..., label**N**).

Later, they can iterate them with the loop and add them in the blink of an eye. After, they can manipulate them from the object (labels) like before labels(0), labels(1), etc.

There are 3 points to take into consideration:

 1. A `List` can be used to emulate the large collection of controls.
 2. `typeof(Control)` helps us define the type of the control to add to the list.
 3. The **"index"** defined as the last character *(label**1**, label**2**, ..., label**N**)* is the key. This helps us create a logical order.

Furthermore, here is another example running created **design mode** using **Text Boxes**:

[![Many text boxes in one window][3]][3]

**Running:**

[![running example][4]][4]

  [1]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/a2NLj.png
  [2]: https://mir-s3-cdn-cf.behance.net/project_modules/max_1200/3624de11048267.560f05aecb9e9.jpg
  [3]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/uyCjW.png
  [4]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/atES2.png
**Will this feature affect UI controls?**

Up to a certain point. It might need a new property called Index or something that relates to this feature. I'd say a similar code to the one I shared can be used in the background. Also, another property might be needed to identify if it's an array.

<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/main/docs/issue-guide.md -->

netcoreapp3.1

<!-- Yes / No -->

No

**Problem description:**

<!--
    Describe the current behavior, what is wrong or not working as expected.
    Provide as much information as possible, including callstack for crashes/exceptions, screenshots or animations.
  -->

WindowsFormsApp1.csproj
```csproj
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk.WindowsDesktop">

  <PropertyGroup>
    <OutputType>WinExe</OutputType>
    <TargetFramework>netcoreapp3.1</TargetFramework>
    <UseWindowsForms>true</UseWindowsForms>
  </PropertyGroup>

</Project>
```

Form1.cs
```cs
using System;
using System.Collections.Generic;
using System.ComponentModel;
using System.Data;
using System.Drawing;
using System.Linq;
using System.Text;
using System.Threading.Tasks;
using System.Windows.Forms;

namespace WindowsFormsApp2
{
    public partial class Form1 : Form
    {
        public Form1()
        {
            InitializeComponent();
            Console.WriteLine("TEST");    // Add only this line.
        }

    }
}
```

**Expected behavior:**

- `TEST` is output to `OUTPUT`. (Like .Net Framework Forms app)

Please tell me how to output string to `OUTPUT`.

**Minimal repro:**

1. use Microsoft Visual Studio Community 2019 Version 16.8.5
1. Create `Windows Forms App(.NET)`
1. Add only `Console.WriteLine("TEST");`

Issues.Title: Fix IPerPropertyBrowsing on 64 bit
Issues.Body:
IPerPropertyBrowsing.GetPredefinedStrings would fail on 64bit as it would try to marshal an array of integers as IntPtrs.

The first commit makes a more targeted change. The code was terribly inefficient, so the 3rd commit simplifies the marshalling significantly. 2nd commit is just some style clean in prep for the third.

Please do not squash the PR so we can reference the fix for the original marshalers if we need to port to .NET Framework.

Also:

- Ordered HRESULTs
- Add test helpers to validate COM memory handling

We don't have a great way to test this end-to-end as there aren't COM Controls readily available on a standard Win10 box that implement this API (afaik).

Issues.Title: System.Windows.Forms.Padding is missing "TypeForwardedFrom" attribute.
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 
net6.0 and possibly Net5.0+
* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
No

**Problem description:**
"Padding" was moved around and is now in a new binary specific to core. However, this type is missing "TypeForwardedFrom" attribute. Every type that have  "TypeforwardTo" attribute should have "TypeForwardedFrom". We may need to scan "System.Windows.Forms.Primitive.dll" and see if any other types in it need this change.

**Expected behavior:**

"TypeForwardedFrom" attributes  on the types that were moved around in the "System.Windows.Forms.Primitive.dll"
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "System.Windows.Forms.Padding is missing "TypeForwardedFrom" attribute." (#4561)

Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/main/docs/issue-guide.md -->

**.NET Core Version:**
- 6.0.0-alpha.1.21073.5

**Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?:**
- Yes (4.7.2)

**Minimal repro:**
[Simple example.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/5970977/Issue-4458.zip)
1. Create ListView with 9 items
2. Set `SmallIcon` view
3. Add couple columns to ListView
4. The ListView should display items as follows:
```
1 2 3
4 5 6
7 8 9
```
5. Execute `FindNearestItem(SearchDirectionHint.Down)` for `1` and `4` items.

**Actual behavior:**
The "FindNearestItem" method returns `7` for `1` element
The "FindNearestItem" method returns `null` for `4` element
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23376742/107754156-27e45580-6d32-11eb-81ab-87da52d25888.png)

**Expected behavior:**
The "FindNearestItem" method should return `4` for `1` element
The "FindNearestItem" method should return `7` for `4` element
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "The "FindNearestItem" method incorrectly identifies the item at the bottom when the ListView has "SmallIcon" view" (#4558)

Issues.Title: Broken custom IDataObject implementations
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/main/docs/issue-guide.md -->

* .NET Core Version: 5.0

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?:  No

**Problem description:**

PR #3388 removed the `ComVisible` attribute from `System.Windows.Forms.IDataObject`. That largely breaks the marshaling custom implementation of `IDataObject` through clipboard *within the same application*. The concern about marshaling of individual calls is not applicable in that case because the runtime could resolve the `IDataObject` to the original .NET object implementation.

It likely broke this case in `Clipboard.GetDataObject` and now all returned objects are wrapped in the default `DataObject` which doesn't support all the custom types:
https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/2fd2a5840b345ef83e0d15a91747325af27441f1/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/Clipboard.cs#L170-L173

**Expected behavior:**

Issues.Title: Fixing IndexOutOfRangeException throwing by DGV when disposing its DataSource
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please read CONTRIBUTING.md before submitting a pull request -->

Fixes #4216


## Proposed changes

- Add Dispose event handlers to clear DataSource of DGV and BindingSource of BindingNavigator thereby update their data source actual state

<!-- We are in TELL-MODE the following section must be completed -->

## Customer Impact

- A user won't catch the exception when closing a form or disposing a BindingSource

## Regression? 

- Yes and no. .NET Framework 4.8 throws an exception when closing a form. v.4.7 doesn't throw the exception in this case. But anyway every version throws the exception if to Dispose a BindingSource component

## Risk

- Minimal

<!-- end TELL-MODE -->


## Screenshots <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->

### Before
- A DataGridView doesn't update its Rows and Columns collections after its DataSource is disposed. And the DGV throws the exception when trying to redraw because the DGV is trying to draw items from a DataSource that doesn't already exist (send some index, eg. 4, to the collection that has 0 items, and catch IndexOutOfRangeException)
![vR6xyN1oe6](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49272759/107550604-49cec280-6be2-11eb-848d-d137900e1a07.gif)

<!-- TODO -->

### After
- DataGridView and BindingNavigator subscribed on the BindingSource Disposed event and release their DataSource and BindingSource to update internal collections
![mtA3PmfUl4](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49272759/107550667-5d7a2900-6be2-11eb-8299-757cc49e73af.gif)

<!-- TODO -->


## Test methodology <!-- How did you ensure quality? -->

- Unit testing
- Manual UI testing
- CTI

## Test environment(s) <!-- Remove any that don't apply -->

- .NET 6.0.100-preview.1.21101.5
- Microsoft Windows [Version 10.0.19042.804]


<!-- Mention language, UI scaling, or anything else that might be relevant -->
